title: Georgian-Style Manor in England’s Cotswolds Asks £2.25 million
text:
Though it might look like a centuries-old stately home, this English manor house in the well-to-do countryside region of the Cotswolds, dates back only to the 1960s.



Dubbed Shipton Standing, the Georgian-style house in the village of Shipton-under-Wychwood, Oxfordshire, hit the market Thursday asking £2.25 million (US$2.8 million).



Built in 1963 by architect Alan Gore, the house has more recently been extensively renovated and improved by the current owners, according to the listing with Savills.

The owners—who Mansion Global couldn’t identify—created a new kitchen and dining room by combining two rooms, installed new bathrooms and enhanced the Georgian-style interior by adding new skirting boards, window architraves and a neoclassical fireplace.



“What a house,” listing agent Charles Elsmore-Wickens said in a statement. “It wows you from the moment you walk in the front door. This is probably the best Georgian-style house I have seen that's not Georgian.”



The six-bedroom house has a sitting room with large sash windows, a wood-burning fireplace, and French doors to the garden. The newly renovated kitchen is an open plan space in which to cook, eat and entertain, the listing said.

The kitchen’s bespoke cabinetry is hand painted and has been designed to be visually impressive against the high ceilings and large volume of space in the room, and the room has direct access to the home’s terrace, according to the listing.



The house also has a cozy study and a basement that’s currently used as a TV and games room, but could equally serve as a cinema space or den.



Outside, the grounds extend to almost an acre with a walled garden and mature trees and shrubs.
